thread.title: England's David Howell up to number 36 in world chess rankings
thread.title_full: England's David Howell up to number 36 in world chess rankings - Telegraph

author: Malcolm Pein , Chess correspondent
title: England's David Howell up to number 36 in world chess rankings
text: David Howell achieved another all-time high on the rating list after a fantastic performance at the Leiden Open, where he stormed to victory with 8.5/9. Howell reached 2712 and a world ranking of 36. Here is a splendid win from Leiden. Black ought to have known better – the theory of this line was partially developed at the 4NCL. • British Chess Championships: David Howell begins defence of title Howell had a good grasp of the nuances. If 11.f3 Nc6 12.Be3 Bb4+ 13.Kf2 Na5 with lots of counterplay 12...Nc6 is attempting to improve the stunning game Hammer-Edouard that decided the 2014 4NCL after 12...Qd5 13.Ne1 but 13.Ra7 is good. D. Howell – A. Das Queen’s Gambit Accepted 1.d4 d5 2.c4 dxc4 3.e4 b5 4.a4 c6 5.Nc3 a6 6.axb5 cxb5 7.Nxb5 axb5 8.Rxa8 Bb7 9.Ra1 e6 10.Be2 Nf6 11.Nf3! Nxe4 12.0–0 Nc6 13.b3 Na5 (13...Nc3 14.Qc2 Nxe2+ 15.Qxe2 Qd5 16.bxc4 Nxd4 with confusion looks best) 14.Bxc4! bxc4 15.bxc4 (Howell has introduced the possibility of Qa4+ which cause all kinds of disruption, as the black king is in the centre) 15...Nc3 16.Qd3 Bb4 17.d5 Nb3 (17...Ba6 18.Ne5 0–0 19.Ba3 Bxa3 20. Qxc3 with the hilarious sight of three black pieces on the a-file) 18.Ba3! Nc5 19.Qe3 Qa5 20.Bb2! N3a4 21.Bxg7 (Quite extraordinary; Black has five pieces out of play) 21...Rg8 22.Bd4 Rg4 23.Rfb1 Re4 24.Qg5 Rxd4 (24...Nd7 25.dxe6 Qxg5 26.exd7+ Kxd7 27.Nxg5 Rxd4 28.Rxa4 Be7 29.Ra7) 25.Nxd4 Bc3 26.Qg8+ Ke7 27.Rxb7+ 1–0 Michael Adams missed several good opportunities at Biel and lost a couple of games, but won a brilliant game against David Navara to reach 3/6. Navara-Rapport Biel round three; Black has just promoted his a-pawn and if 48.Rxa1 Bxf7 draws. How did Navara force resignation? English chess number two David Howell's rating goes above 2700 during the Leiden Open. pic.twitter.com/7jAao1MC8X — John Saunders (@johnchess) July 20, 2015 Answer: 48.Rd8+! 1-0 48...Kb7 49.Bxa1 Bd6+ 50.Rxd6! telegraph.co.uk Follow @telegraph
